Understate: The claim may understate the fact that there is no specific prohibition in the Constitution preventing the confirmation of Judge Amy Coney Barrett in an election year.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the move to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett is "not constitutional" without providing sufficient evidence or legal basis to support this assumption.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the assertion that the move to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett is "not constitutional" according to legal experts.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations or arguments that support the constitutionality of the Senate Republicans' move to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no clause in the Constitution that would prevent the confirmation of a Supreme Court nominee close to Election Day.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the unconstitutionality of the Senate Republicans' move to confirm Judge Amy Coney Barrett without providing sufficient evidence to support this claim.
Falters at times: The claim may falter in providing a clear and well-supported argument regarding the constitutionality of the Senate Republicans' move.
